Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a bit about ancient philosophy.

I learned about the views of Plato, Aristotle, the Stoics, and the Epicureans about a happy life. I'm not totally sure I grasped their final points but I did get to read some of the Republic and the Ethics, so I feel cultured (when it comes to Western philosophy). This was my first philosophy course so I also learned about philosophical inquiry and how to deconstruct an argument.

I learned to write a philosophy paper which is very different to typical research papers written in college. I also learned to critically read a philosopher's text, identify arguments (premises and conclusions), and present objections to their argument.
Survey of Ancient Greek Philosophy
Decent intro to philosophical thought in antiquity, good practice in argument deconstruction

The course gave me a good overview or many viewpoints of ancient philosophy, particularly focusing on Plato and Aristotle. It also gave me experience writing historical philosophy papers, blending the analysis of a philosophy paper with the exegesis of a historical paper.
Mainly knowledge about the views of different ancient philosophers: Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, Stoics, Epicureans, etc.

Learned a lot about Plato and Aristotle, with a bit about the pre-Socratics, and a lecture devoted to each the Epicurians and the Stoics. Skillwise learned about how to deconstruct a philosophic argument in our papers.

Knowledge on ancient phiolosophy (especially Plato and Aristotle)
How to write a philosophy paper
Better analytical skills while reading passages

The main takeaway I had from this course was learning the writings and beliefs of ancient philosophers. I now know more about the beliefs of writers like Plato, Aristotle, Epicurus, and others, which will hopefully help me understand the writings of other, more recent, philosophers. I also got more experience writing and discussing philosophy - I feel more confident in my philosophy skills (while still acknowledging that there is plenty of room to grow) and I have a better idea of whether I want to continue philosophy. It was a worthwhile class to get a better handle on the fundamentals of philosophy.
A philosophical mode of thinking and an ability to closely analyze texts.
PHIL 125 did a good job of teaching effective close reading of philosophical texts. There was also a good focus on how to engage critically with various ideas and positions.
An overview of ancient philosophies in light of readings and analysis of translated texts.
Learned basics about different groups in ancient Philosophy as well as some more about Plato and Aristotle, the focuses (foci?) of the course.
Techniques for reading philosophy and developing and organized way of mapping ancient texts.
how to write a basic philosophy paper
I learned how to think deeply about major philosophical problems and evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of an argument.
I gained a great foundation in the theories of the greatest (western) ancient philosophers.
I learned about ancient philosophers and how to write philosophical papers

I gained a strong foundation in the important ancient Mediterranean thinkers-- I really feel I learned a lot about especially Plato and Aristotle's philosophies. Also learned about writing history of philosophy type papers.

PHIL 125 was an interesting course that gave me insights into the basics of ancient philosophy, mostly focusing on two prominent figures: Aristotle and Plato. Because of its introductory nature, the course offered a general and broad scheme of information in the field of ancient Greek philosophy. The course's discussion section allowed for more in depth conversations on the topics covered in class, and thus helped me understand the material in a more holistic way, while I gained the insight of my classmates into the texts read. The course gave me a solid foundation on the texts that it covered, as it introduced me to the philosophies of some of the most widely-acclaimed philosophers that have ever lived. Furthermore, another aspect of the course that I found of particular interest was the way in which it helped me with expressing my ideas in writing. PHIL 125, and especially the TAs, gave me very comprehensive feedback on my writing and helped me develop my writing skills, especially in the sense of academic, philosophical writing.
This course helps you to develop skills for reading complex philosophical texts, disecting the meaning within, and expressing these ideas in essays.
Although this course is a writing credit, there was virtually no instruction on how to write a philosophy paper.

Strengths: requires a very minimal amount of work.

Weaknesses: the course is graded quite difficultly, and many of the topics seem extremely far-fetched. I know no philosophy professor wants to admit it, but a lot of ancient philosophy is simply outdated and verifiably wrong. I would've preferred if more time was spent on things that still had connections to the world today, such as Plato's critique of democracy, and not spent so much time on things such as whether magnets have souls.

This course is very well organized, as Professor Harte provides handouts with each lecture and explains the concepts very clearly. She is always glad to take questions and elaborate further. The workload for this class is also pretty light and the grading is generous (your worst paper only counts 10%).

Strengths: interesting material, intellectually stimulating to think about the subjects that the philosophers write about
Weaknesses: hard to stay interested on a weekly basis if you don't do the readings and go to lecture.
The handouts are really helpful
The workload's not to bad and some of the lectures are really interesting. That being said, there were the occasionally weeks where Professor Harte talked way above most of the classes heads.

Sometimes the topics could be hard to follow, and it was very easy to get lost during a lecture. Prof. Harte provided handouts containing lecture notes which were very helpful, but the course could have been improved by using more of the blackboard to help more visual learners like me.

Strengths: Great overview of ancient greek philosophy
Weaknesses: Class can get boring and kind of repetitive at points - seems like learning the same thing over and over again at points but with slight variations

Strengths are in Professor Hart's knowledge and passion for the subject. It's not the most engaging lecture but if you pay attention you'll learn a ton and it'll be worth it. Although I do wish we'd spent some more time with philosophers besides Plato and Aristotle.

You don't really need to attend any lecture to do well on this course, since the grades are basically purely from papers. So someone with a strong philosophy background can just type out their papers and never go to class and do better someone that was critically engaged the whole way through.

The course contents are interesting
sometimes we dive deep into some side topics and lost track

The essays were difficult to write, and when taken into the account the feedback for the next essay(s), my grade was not improved. There wasnt a clear grading structure to the essays and it felt like I was trying really hard to improve but getting no where.

The strengths of the class was the readings, which were picked out very carefully (and therefore kept at a relatively manageable level). Also, we had plenty of options for our essays, and they were spaced out well, so that kept the workload to a more manageable level. However, I thought a weakness of the class was explaining the writings more clearly. While the lectures were very effective, I still often found myself confused by the text - I found myself recording lectures to play them back later, and I think that recording this class would be very effective at helping students engage fully with the material.

Overall it introduced us to important philosophical texts extremely well, given that most of us had had no exposure to them beforehand. Occasionally it felt like a section only dealt with a small portion of the week's reading, which was disappointing if we had focused on a different part. I might recommend having narrower readings so that everyone is on the same page.

Section was a big strong point (TA's take a lot of time to ensure that every member of the section is getting what they need out of the material). It might've been helpful to focus on the big picture history of ideas and how they connect with one another

The papers allowed really deep readings of small sections which seems similar to what academic "History of Philosophy" is. The Teaching fellows were all really nice and clearly knowledgeable about the material. Professor Harte is obviously an expert and is able to address any portion of any of the texts and clearly has a deep understanding of them. 
The two main weaknesses were the lecture style and the amount of readings. First, Professor Harte's voice has a certain quality which makes it difficult to engage with what she is saying for the hour of class time. The handouts help, but it can all blur together as she doesn't really breakup her lecture, giving it the form of one continuous 50 minute monologue which can be hard to find engaging due to the monotone which she sometimes uses. In terms of reading it was manageable, but as evidenced by the papers it would be possible to spend hours reading just small portions (just a couple of pages) of the text, while we were regularly assigned 20-30 pages twice a week. This made it seem that I was missing out on a deep understanding of all we read as I wasn't able to spend hours and hours on every reading.
Strengths involve great teacher and TF. The readings were sometimes long but expected.

It covers a lot of the basics of ancient philosophy. However, they expect too much out of people who have never written a philosophy paper. They graded unreasonably hard despite the amount of work many students put in.
The section was the best part of the course. I also appreciated Prof. Harte's attention to detail.
Discussion sections could focus more on discussion and less on group work or general questions students have, because that would be the most helpful for the class.

I really liked how the history and philosophy were intertwined and still engaged critical thinking (eg in actually debating philosophical theories instead of just learning about them). But I wish there was more of this latter engagement (though I understand that it is difficult in a history of ancient philosophy class).

The strengths of the course lie mainly on its discussion section, and its structure. It was structured in such a way that it allowed for a very comprehensive introduction to ancient philosophy, as it started from the pre-Socratic philosophers and gradually moved on to the Socratics, the Platonists, the Epicureans, and the Stoics, always building up on pre-existing knowledge and making connections between the philosophers. It managed to convey some of the core values and beliefs of ancient philosophers in a way that was understandable for university students in the 21st century. Nonetheless, the course did not only present the ideas of the philosophers, but also it fostered an aspect of discussion, and that is something that was widely reflected on the nature of the discussion sections. The discussion section was for me an integral part of the course, as it allowed for the exchange of ideas and for the in-depth analysis of the texts that were read and presented in lecture. The TA did a very good job managing the discussion and guiding us within the complicated and many times outdated texts and opinions of the philosophers. Even though the course was very well organized and taught, I feel that there were some minor aspects of it that could be improved. One of them would be the lack of meaningful interaction in the lectures, something that may have caused them to be tiring and monotonous at times. Furthermore, the last lecture (the Survivor island lecture) was something that I thoroughly, and I wish that we could have been given some more time and guidance in order to prepare for it, but also in order to experience it.
The course has a light workload, so students can choose what extent they would like to engage with it. The course also offers a variety of texts from Greek philosophers.
Yes, Professor Harte is a great lecturer and helps you understand the material.

If you do not enjoy vagueness, do not take this class. I would only recommend this course for someone who intends on pursuing philosophy as a major. I would not recommend this course for a writing credit. It very much feels as if it is assumed that you know philosophy to some technical degree and that you know how to write a philosophy paper.

It's a relatively small amount of work for a writing credit, so that's a plus. However, you need to be able to get through difficult concepts, especially if you care about getting a good grade. So shop it, but be wary.

I took this course as an introduction to the field of philosophy and was pleased with the experience. It's definitely one of the better courses with Intro in the title. If you're more interested in a more specific field of philosophy, like ethics, maybe look for one of those courses (though they're probably harder), but this was a nice general exposure to the subject.
I would recommend this course to students who need a writing credit or who are interested in taking an introductory course in philosophy.
Well, if you are fine with Aristotle, take this course. Otherwise you are going to hate 1/3 of it.
Not unless you're filling a major requirement. Over all it was a comparatively difficult WR credit that'll hurt your gpa.
I would take this course only if you know you like philosophy - it might be kind of mundane for those who don't enjoy the material, since you'd still have to learn some of it for the papers.
Would recommend if interested in Plato and Aristotle, great intro class to philosophy
Not entirely. It felt like a dead end no matter how many hours I put into the papers and with the advice from the professor and TA, I would still get a low grade.

I would recommend this course to a student if they wanted to learn more about the fundamentals of philosophy and determine whether they wanted to major in it (or at least take further classes). If, instead, they were only interested in taking one philosophy class to broaden their horizons, but they weren't actually interested in the major, this might not be the best class to take (I recommend any class with Shelly Kagan).
Yes, very highly. Its subject and methods are important for understanding history, literature, and thought, and everyone should get some exposure to it.
I would recommend this course to any student looking to sharpen their analytical thinking and writing abilities.
Yes - philosophy is an important stream of knowledge, while an analytical reading of texts is a great skill. This is a good introductory level course that starts at the very beginning.
Yes. Reasonably paced reading schedule with very well chosen texts.
Yes. Learned lots of ancient philosophy and really learned to enjoy writing descriptive philosophy essays
Yes, a good introduction to philosophy and way to acclimate oneself with writing philosophy papers in college.

No, the papers aren't long but their expectations are unreasonable. If you aren't one of the most amazing writers, I definitely do not recommend. It's graded really hard and despite seeing TAs and working with the professor it can still be impossible to do well.
Yes, I thought it gave a great introduction, and the TAs were really helpful.

Well, if you're a philosophy major, it doesn't really matter whether I recommend this course because you're gonna have to take it anyway. If you're not a philosophy major, then I probably wouldn't recommend, unless you have a particular fascination with ancient philosophy. Personally, I prefer more modern stuff. That said, this course was by no means a bad experience. The workload was low (like reeeally low), and professor Harte was good. So no complaints. Could make a good fifth class.

I would recommend this class to another student. I feel like I got a solid foundation and got what I wanted out of the class, but would say only a student that KNOWS they are interested in the HISTORY of philosophy should take the class.
Yes. The course is challenging, despite there only being three papers all semester. Philosophy classes are more challenging than I realized, but definitely rewarding

I had to take this class for the philosophy major, but I was pleasantly surprised by it. The content is interesting and important to know for working in Western philosophy. I'd recommend it to people interested in the major, especially if professor Harte is teaching it

I would definitely recommend this course to somebody who is interested in learning about Ancient Greek philosophy, and especially somebody who wants to get acquainted with the topics of it. As I mentioned above, the course gives a very comprehensive introduction to the field of ancient philosophy, and hence will allow for a good, foundational course for somebody who is interested in that field. There is no required background in philosophy for this course.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone who has an interest in philosophy or ancient Greece. The course delves into many interesting topics in these areas.
Course was fine, but I probably would not recommend unless you think you want to be a philosophy major
